person.persName: John Urtaya, Archimandrite of the Convent of John Urtaya

residence.note: John Urtaya resided in the Convent of John Urtaya.

event.desc:
The Convent of John Urtaya was founded in
A.D. 388 (700 of Alexander)

The Convent of John Urtaya closed in
A.D. 566 (878 Alexander)

The great senior Mar Samuel Archpresbyter dwelled in the Convent of John Urtaya during the time of its prosperity until the year
A.D. 538 (850 Alexander)

person.persName:
Mar Samuel, Archpresbyter of
Convent of John Urtaya in Amida

residence.note: Mar Samuel resided in Convent of John Urtaya in Amida.

event.desc:
Mar Samuel gained distinction in the conflict of persecution. He went into exile in the district of Claudias where he took up residence in the convent of the Huts. He related the story of the establishment of the Convent of John Urtaya to John of Ephesus. This occurred
before A.D. 536.

residence.note:
Mar Samuel resided in the convent of the Huts in the district of
Claudias .

event.desc:
Mar Samuel died in
A.D. 539
Before the Convent of John Urtaya was established there were a collection of huts on the site, named after Mar Afwrsm.

Mar John built a hut near the huts of Mar Afwrsm in the year
A.D. 700

John went about preaching and teaching the Christian faith in Urtaye and spoke the language of Urtaye. As such, many believed that John was Urtaya and called him by that name. John was actually Syrian.

birth.note: John Urtaya was born in Syria.

event.desc: John Urtaya's fame spread far and wide, attracting many followers including two excellent scribes from the Convent of Edessa at Amida, Samuel and Johnathan.

occupation.note:
Samuel was a monk in
the Convent of the Edessenes.

Samuel was a scribe in
the Convent of the Edessenes.

residence.note: Samuel resided in the Convent of the Edessenes.

occupation.note:
Johnathan was a monk in
the Convent of the Edessenes

Johnathan was a scribe in
the Convent of the Edessenes

residence.note: Johnathan resided in the Convent of the Edessenes

event.desc: During the time that Johnathan and Samuel lived with Mar John Urtaya, they learned a great deal about asceticism and the Christian faith. The convent flourished, buildings were established, and the brotherhood grew to fifty in number.

residence.note: Samuel came to reside in the Convent of John Urtaya in Amida.
Johnathan came to reside in the Convent of John Urtaya in Amida.

personGrp.persName:
The monks who resided in
the Convent of John Urtaya in Amida

occupation.note:
These men were monks in
the Convent of John Urtaya in Amida

residence.note: These monks resided in the Convent of John Urtaya in Amida.

event.desc: John of Urtaya died.
Samuel succeeded John of Urtaya as the head of the convent.

occupation.note:
Samuel was the archimandrite of
the Convent of John Urtaya in Amida

event.desc: Johnathan, who had left the monastery while John Urtaya was still alive, returned after his death and lived in a brotherly fashion with Samuel.
Samuel died.
Johnathan succeeded Samuel as head of the convent.

occupation.note:
Johnathan was archimandrite of
the Convent of John Urtaya in Amida.

event.desc: Johnathan governed the convent well before he died.
Job succeeded Johnathan as head of the convent.

person.persName:
Job, Archimandrite of
the Convent of John Urtaya in Amida

occupation.note:
Job was the archimandrite of
the Convent of John Urtaya in Amida.

event.desc: Job governed the monastery well before he died.
Abraham succeeded Job as head of the convent.

person.persName:
Abraham I, Archimandrite of
the Convent of John Urtaya in Amida

occupation.note:
Abraham was an archimandrite of
the Convent of John Urtaya in Amida

event.desc: Abraham was from Amida and had a residence there. His mother, brothers, and kinsmen lived in Amida.

residence.note: Abraham's mother resided in Amida.
Abraham's brothers resided in Amida.
Abraham's kinsmen resided in Amida.

event.desc: The monks serving under Abraham accused him of embezzling monastery funds in order to support his family. Abraham was innocent, but left the monastery to live in the city and lived the rest of his days longing for his former monastic existence.

personGrp.persName: The monks who accused Abraham of embezzlement

residence.note: Abraham resided in his home in Amida.

event.desc: Abraham II succeeded Abraham I as the head of the convent.

person.persName:
Abraham II, Archimandrite of
the Convent of John Urtaya in Amida

occupation.note:
Abraham was the archimandrite of
the Convent of John Urtaya in Amida

event.desc:
As Abraham's reputation as an excellent leader grew, King Zeno gifted him with a village in
Narda in the district of
Ingelene
Abraham gave half of the land that he received from the king to the brothers of the Monastery of Zurknin.

personGrp.persName:
The brothers of
the Monastery of Zurknin

residence.note: The brothers resided in the Monastery of Zurknin.

event.desc: The Convent of John Urtaya grew to include 400 brothers.
Abraham was promoted to the bishopric in Urtaye in the district of Anzetene.

occupation.note:
Abraham was Bishop of
Urtaye in the district of Anzetene.

event.desc: The monks of the Convent of John Urtaya urged Bishop Abraham to appoint a new head. Abraham chose a reluctant old monk, also named Abraham, who was formerly a shepherd from the Village of Thella d Mikhana.
Abraham the Shepherd succeeded Abraham II as head of the Convent of John Urtaya

birth.note: Abraham was born in village of Thella d Mikhana.

event.desc: The monks of the Convent of John of Urtaya disliked Abraham II's appointment of Abraham the shepherd as his successor, believing him to be a lowly peasant. Sixty men left the Convent of John Urtaya.

personGrp.persName: The sixty monks who left the Convent of John Urtaya.

event.desc:
The sixty men who left the monastery established a
monastery in Beth Bar 'rubtha.
Mar Samuel, prior to founding Mar Samuel Convent, he visited the Convent of John Urtaya.
Mar Samuel stood on a column for a time before he began to build his convent. Abraham III sent his monks to help Mar Samuel build the convent.

Kawad, King of Persia attacked the City of Amida, slaughtered many people, took captives, and razed the Convent of John Urtaya in the year
A.D. 814
The story of Kawad's invasion was related to John of Ephesus years later when he was a white haired man, living in the Monastery of mar Thomas at Beth Gubrin.

person.persName:
The white-haired man from the monastery at
Beth Gubrin

residence.note: This monk resided in a monastery at Beth Gubrin.

event.desc: King Kawad's invasion was devastating and drove many away from the Convent of John Urtaya. The old man fled from Amida.
Another old man, named Paul of Arzen, related the history of the Convent of John of Urtaya to John of Ephesus.
Paul was a monk in the Convent of John Urtaya when there were 400 monks residing within its walls, and shortly before King Kawad's invasion of Amida.
Because King Kawad's invasion destroyed the Convent of John Urtaya, Paul took up residence in the Monastery of Orientals at Edessa.

residence.note: Paul resided in the Convent of the Orientals in Edessa.

event.desc:
Paul died during the second persecution
sometime after A.D. 536.
The Convent of John Urtaya was rebuilt after King Kawad's invasion, but on a smaller scale--both in the number of buildings erected and in the number of monks admitted.
Abraham III died
Cosmas succeeded Abraham III as head of the Convent of John Urtaya and served in the reign of the Emperor Anastasius.

occupation.note:
Cosmas was an archimandrite of
Convent of John Urtaya

event.desc: Cosmas died
Sergius succeeded Cosmas as head of the Convent of John Urtaya.

occupation.note:
Sergius was the archimandrite of
the Convent of John Urtaya

event.desc:
Sergius died in the first persecution in the monastery of
Mar Mama

Symy succeeded Sergius I as the head of the Convent of John Urtaya in
A.D. 522
Symy prophesied many things that came to pass, including his own death three and a half years after assuming the office of archimandrite.

Symy died three and a half years after assuming office in
the Convent of the Poplars in
A.D. 526

The monks of the Convent of John Urtaya who were in exile during the first persecution were allowed to return to their convent and inter Symy's bones there in
A.D. 530
Abba succeeds Symy as head of the Convent of John Urtaya.

The Emperor Justinian began his reign in
A.D. August 1, 527
The persecution was renewed through the descent of Ephraim and all of the convents were expelled in

occupation.note: Ephraim was the patriarch of Antioch.

event.desc: Abba and his monks went into exile and took up residence in the convent of the Poplars

personGrp.persName: The monks of the Convent of John Urtaya who accompanied Abba into exile.

residence.note: Abba resided in the Convent of the Poplars.
The monks who followed Abba into exile resided in the Convent of the Poplars.

event.desc: Abba and his monks were expelled from the Convent of the Poplars and took up residence in the Convent of Nut in the village of 'Bdhyr.

residence.note: Abba resided in the Convent of Nut.
The monks who went into exile with Abba resided in the Convent of Nut.

event.desc: After three years of residing in the Convent of Nut, Abba and his monks went to live in the Monastery of the Huts.

residence.note: Abba resided in the Monastery of the Huts.
The monks who followed Abba into exile resided in the Monastery of the Huts.

event.desc: Abba continued to be persecuted and fled to the court of Empress Theodora.
Abba returned to the Convent of the Huts and died.
Abraham IV succeeded Abba as head of the Convent of John Urtaya.

birth.note: Abraham IV was born in Anzetene.

event.desc: Abraham IV died and was buried in the monastery.
Sergius of Amida succeeded Abraham IV as head of the Convent of John Urtaya
Sergius gained distinction in exile during the persecutions and embraced asceticism and abstinence.

person.persName: Sergius II, archimandrite of the Convent of John Urtaya

occupation.note:
Sergius was the archimandrite of
the Convent of John Urtaya

socecStatus.note: Sergius belonged to a distinguished family called the house of Bar Deba.

event.desc:
Emperor Justinian died in the year
A.D. 565 (877 Alexander).

The brothers of the Convent of John Urtaya and the other religious believers persevered during the persecutions, which began in
A.D. 520 (832 Alexander)
and continued until the writing of this account in the year
A.D. 567 (879 Alexander).
